page.title: 2.2.0: Lesson Overview
page.contents:
In this lesson, you will activate and build on what you have learned about solving by substitution, or replacing a variable with a number or with an expression. Various substitutions can be done to solve the same system. You will also begin to build an awareness of the kinds of systems that are conducive to being solved by substitution.

When you finish this lesson, you will be able to:

  • Solve systems of equations by substituting a variable or an expression.
  • Know more than one way to perform a substitution and decide which way or what to substitute based on how the given equations are written.

Here are the activities that will help you reach those goals:

  • 2.2.1: Finding Connections between Graphs and Equations
  • 2.2.2: Checking Solutions in Systems
  • 2.2.2: Self Check 
  • 2.2.3: Solving Equations Using Substitution
  • 2.2.3: Self Check 
  • 2.2.4: Solving More Equations

After that, you’ll practice and review.

  • 2.2.5: Practice
  • 2.2.6: Lesson Summary

page.title: 2.2.1: Finding Connections between Graphs and Equations
page.contents:
Here are graphs of two equations in a system.

     


Determine if each of these systems could be represented by the graphs. Be prepared to explain how you know.

\( \begin{cases} x + 2y = 8 \\x = -5 \end{cases} \)

\( \begin{cases} y = -7x + 13 \\y = -1 \end{cases} \)

\( \begin{cases} 3x = 8\\3x + y = 15 \end{cases} \)

\( \begin{cases} y = 2x - 7\\4 + y = 12 \end{cases} \)

Enter your answer here

This question involves relying on what you know about horizontal and vertical lines, intercepts, and slope to determine if the graphs could represent each pair of equations. Check if the equation of either line in the system represents a vertical line. If there is a vertical line, determine on which side of the \(y\)-axis the line would be. Finally, check if the slope of the non-vertical line is negative.


Correct answers are:

a. No. The graph for \(x = -5\) would be on the left side of the vertical axis, which is not what’s shown.

b. No. The graph for \(y = -1\) would be a horizontal line, but no horizontal line is shown.

c. Yes. \(3x = 8\) can be rearranged into \(x=\frac83\). The graph for \(x=\frac83\) is a vertical line to the right of the vertical axis. \(3x + y = 15\) can be rewritten as \(y = -3x + 15\). Its graph has a negative slope and a positive \(y\)-value for the vertical intercept.

d. No. The graph for \(y = 2x - 7\) would have a positive slope and a negative \(y\)-value for the vertical intercept, neither of which matches the given graphs.

page.title: 2.2.2: Additional Resources
page.contents:
Solving Systems of Linear Equations

Let’s solve this system of linear equations using the substitution method.

\(\left\{\begin{array}{l}2x\;+\;y\;=\;7\\x\;-\;2y\;=\;6\end{array}\right.\)


We will first solve one of the equations for either \(x\) or \(y\). We can choose either equation and solve for either variable—but we’ll try to make a choice that will keep the work easy.

Then we substitute that expression into the other equation. The result is an equation with just one variable—and we know how to solve those!

After we find the value of one variable, we will substitute that value into one of the original equations and solve for the other variable. Finally, we check our solution and make sure it makes both equations true.

How to Solve a System of Equations by Substitution

Step 1.Solve one of the equations for either variable.

Step 2.Substitute the expression from Step 1 into the other equation.

Step 3. Solve the resulting equation.

Step 4.Substitute the solution from Step 3 into one of the original equations to find the other variable.

Step 5. Write the solution as an ordered pair.

Step 6.Check that the ordered pair is a solution to both original equations.


Solve the system by substitution: \(\left\{\begin{array}{l}2x\;+\;y\;=\;7\\x\;-\;2y\;=\;6\end{array}\right.\)

Solution

Step 1.Solve one of the equations for either variable.

We’ll solve the first equation for y.

\(\begin{array}{c}\left\{\begin{array}{l}2x+y=7\\x-2y=6\end{array}\right.\end{array}\)

\( \begin{array}{rcl}2x+y&=&7\\y&=&7-2x\\&&\end{array}\)

Step 2.Substitute the expression from Step 1 into the other equation.

We replace y in the second equation with the expression 7-2x.

\( \begin{array}{rcl}c-2y&=&6\\x-2(7-2x)&=&6\\&&\end{array}\)

Step 3.Solve the resulting equation.

Now we have an equation with just 1 variable. We know how to solve this!

\( \begin{array}{rcl}x-2(7-2x)&=&6\\x-14+4x&=&6\\5x&=&20\\x&=&4\\&&\end{array}\)

Step 4.Substitute the solution from Step 3 into one of the original equations to find the other variable.

We’ll us the first equation and replace x with 4.

\( \begin{array}{rcl}2x+y&=&7\\2(4)+y&=&7\\8+y&=&7\\y&=&-1\\&&\end{array}\)

Step 5.Write the solution as an ordered pair.

The ordered pair is (x,y).

\((4,1)\)

Step 6.Check that the ordered pair is a solution tobothoriginal equations.

Substitute x=4, y=-1 into both equations and make sure they are both true.

\(\begin{array}{c}2x+y=7\\2(4)+(-1)\overset?=7\\7=7✔\\\end{array}\)

\(\begin{array}{c}x-2y=6\\4-2(-1))\overset?=6\\6=6✔\\\end{array}\)

Both equations are true.

\(4,-1)\) is the solution to the system.

Write down your answer. Then select theSolutionbutton to check your work.

\( y = -11 + 2x \)

Step 2:Replace the \(y\) in the second equation with the expression \( -11 + 2x \).

\( x + 3y = 9 \)

\( x + 3\;{\style{color:red}(}{\style{color:red}–}{\style{color:red}1}{\style{color:red}1}\;{\style{color:red} +}\;{\style{color:red} 2}{\style{color:red}x}{\style{color:red})} = 9 \)

\( x - 33 + 6x = 9 \)

Step 3:Solve the equation with just one variable.

\( x + 3(-11 + 2x) = 9 \)

\( -2x + y = -11 \)

\(-2{\style{color:red}(}{\style{color:red}6}{\style{color:red})} + {\style{color:red}(}{\style{color:red}1}{\style{color:red})}\overset?=-11\)

\( -12 + 1\overset?=-11\)

\( -11 = -11{\style{color:red}✔}\)


\(x + 3y = 9\)

\({\style{color:red}(}{\style{color:red}6}{\style{color:red})} + 3{\style{color:red}(}{\style{color:red}1}{\style{color:red})}\overset?=9\)

\( 9 = 9{\style{color:red} ✔}\)

How did you do? Know that you learn more from wrong answers than from right answers! Wrong answers help us find flaws in our thinking. Take a minute to think about why you got the question wrong. Then you won’t get this type of question wrong again!

page.title: 2.2.4: Solving More Equations
page.contents:
Cool Down Activity

Solve this system of equations without graphing and show your reasoning:

\( \begin{cases} \begin {align} 5x + y&=7 \\20x+2&= y \end {align}\end{cases} \)

Enter your answer here:

\( x = \frac15, y = 6 \). 

Sample strategies:

  • Substituting \( 20x + 2 \) for \( y \) in the first equation, \( 5x+y=7 \), gives \( 5x + (20x+2) = 7 \) or \( 25x + 2 = 7 \), which then gives \( x=\frac15 \). Substituting \( \frac15 \) for \( x \) in the first equation and solving for \( y \) gives \( y=6 \).

  • The first equation, \( 5x+y=7 \), can be rearranged to \( y = 7 - 5x \). Substituting \( 7-5x \) for \( y \) in the second equation gives \( 20x + 2 = 7-5x \). Solving this equation leads to \( x=\frac15 \), and substituting \( \frac15 \) for \( x \) in either equation gives \( y=6 \).

page.title: 2.2.3: Solving Equations Using Substitution
page.contents:
Activity

Solve each system without graphing.

  1. \( \begin{cases} 5x - 2y = 26 \\ y + 4 = x \end{cases} \)

  2. \( \begin{cases} 2m - 2p = -6\\ p = 2m + 10 \end{cases} \)

  3. \( \begin{cases} 2d = 8f \\ 18 - 4f = 2d \end{cases} \)

  4. \( \begin{cases} w + \frac17z = 4 \\ z = 3w -2 \end{cases} \)

Enter your answer here:

There are many ways to solve these equations, graphing and algebraic solving, guessing and checking, or using tables. Answers are:

  1. \( x = 6, y = 2 \)
  2. \( m = -7, p = -4 \)
  3. \( d = 6, f = \frac32 \)
  4. \( w = 3, z = 7 \)

page.title: 2.2.5: Practice
page.contents:
Complete the following questions to practice the skills you have learned in this lesson.

1. Lin is solving this system of equations: 

\( \begin {cases} 6x-5y=34\\3x+2y=8 \end {cases} \)

She starts by rearranging the second equation to isolate the \(y\) variable: \( y = 4 - 1.5x \). She then substitutes the expression \(4 - 1.5x\) for \( y \) in the first equation, as shown:

\( 6x-5(4-1.5x)=34 \)
\( 6x-20-7.5x=34 \)

\( -1.5x=54 \)
\( x=-36 \)


\( y=4-1.5x \)

\( y=4-1.5 \bullet(-36) \)

\( y=58 \)     

Does Lin’s solution of \((-36, 58)\) makes both equations in the system true?

Correct! No; Her solution does not make both equations true.

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 2.2.2. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is that Lin’s solution does not make both equations true. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

Correct! Lin made a multiplication error. The correct answer is x = 4 and y = –2, or (4,–2).

page.title: 2.2.6: Lesson Summary
page.contents:
In this lesson, you learned how to:

  • Solve systems of equations by substituting a variable or an expression.
  • Identify more than one way to perform a substitution and decide how to substitute based on how the given equations are written.

Here are the activities that helped you reach those goals:

  • 2.2.1: Finding Connections between Graphs and Equations
    • In this activity, you analyzed the relationship between systems of equations and their graphs. You determined whether a given graph could represent a specific system of equations using your knowledge of horizontal and vertical lines and the slopes and intercepts of those lines.
  • 2.2.2: Checking Solutions in Systems
    • In this activity, you solved different systems of equations using any method available and then checked your solution by substituting the values found back into the original equations to verify their accuracy.
  • 2.2.2: Self Check
  • 2.2.3: Solving Equations Using Substitution
    • In this activity, you used the substitution method to solve systems of equations. By isolating a variable in one of the equations, you found an equivalent expression that was substituted into the second equation. Using this method, the solution to one variable was found. This value was then substituted back into the first equation to find the value of the remaining unknown variable.2.2.3: Self Check
  • 2.2.4: Solving More Equations
    • In this activity, you continued to solve systems of equations using substitution, but you went a step further by showing your reasoning for each step in the process.

After these activities, you completed the following practice.

  • 2.2.5: Practice
